_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ER Carpenter LP, Temple Pouring Plant was initially built in 1966 to produce prime flexible polyurethane foam for the furniture industry.  The prime line has been expanded and modified several times over the years in order to improve the process, with respect to both equipment and chemistry, to conform to new state and federal regulations while meeting the ever increasing and changing demands of the customers.  New product lines added over the years include bonded carpet underlay made from flexible foam trim and recycled foam, and bonded polyester fiber batting.



Two RMP-regulated substances are used at this facility.  The prime pouring line uses TDI (2-4 toluene and 2-6 toluene diisocyanate), and pentane as a blowing agent.  Pentane is flammable but nontoxic.  The rebond process uses TDI blended with polyol to make a binder to bond the particles together.  No other RMP-regulated substances are used at this facility.



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



ER Carpenter LP, Temple Division, is committed to comply fully with all federal, state, and local rules and regulations regarding the proper handling, use, storage, and emergency response preparedness to prevent accidental releases of chemicals, toxic or otherwise.  Furthermore, ER Carpenter LP is committed to protecting the health and welfare of its employees, the community residents, and the environment.



Our emergency response program is based on the requirements in OSHA's Hazardous Waste and Emergency Operations (HAZWOPER) regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) and both state and local regulations.  The Contingency Plan for the Temple Division includes procedures for proper notification of the local fire department, the police department, and the local hospital, when and if such notification becomes necessary.



2.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Temple Division currently occupies over 532,913 square feet, and is located at 2611 North General Bruce Drive, Tem

ple, TX, 76501.  The plant is bound by Interstate 35 on the north, industrial neighbors on the west, and the Santa Fe tracks and residential neighbors on the east.  Several hundred feet of vacant lot owned by ER Carpenter LP behind the south side of the plant.



The Temple Division manufactures polyurethane foam products for use in furniture carpet cushion underlay, bedding and other applications.  The manufacturing process incorporates the use of TDI (toluene diisocyanate) as a reactant to produce the foam product.  TDI is received by railcar consisting of approximately 185,000 pounds of TDI, and is stored in several indoor storage tanks within the facility.  The largest of which holds approximately 12,200 gallons.  All TDI tanks are located inside the plant within concrete containments.  The TDI is pumped to the mixing head where it is mixed with other reactants to produce a continuous slab of flexible polyurethane foam.  The foam is cut into 50 and 100-foot slabs, and then is stacked in the slab room to cure.



Pentane is used in some foam formulations as a blowing agent.  It is received in tank trucks and is stored outside in a 93,600-pound capacity tank placed within a concrete containment.  The pentane is held under a 3 to 4 psi nitrogen blanket.  The pentane is pumped through underground welded, double wall pipes to the process equipment inside the facility.  There are monitors in the process areas to insure the accumulation of pentane remains well below an explosive mixture.



3.    Worst Case Release Scenario



The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distance for each reported scenario.



TDI:  Assessment and modeling was conducted for a worse case release of TDI from the Temple Division.  The worst case was assumed to be the immediate release of approximately 185,000 pounds of TDI from a railcar at 120degF, onto the rail dock unloading area, which is loca

ted inside the facility.  This temperature per the OCA Guidance Document and SPI Manual, and because in the winter months TDI must be heated to prevent freezing and stratification of the isomers.   TDI has a high boiling point and a low vapor pressure.  This will result in a neutrally buoyant plume close to the density of air.  The EPA RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance Document also indicates that TDI will have a neutrally buoyant plume.



Modeling based on the release of 185,000 pounds of TDI @ 120degF into a containment area of 4,536 ft2, but the amount of TDI would run out of this containment area located inside the facility.  This would result in a worst case scenario of 0.08 miles.  This would place the toxic endpoint beyond the fence line on the other side of the rail tracks, and include some of the residential area.  The population within this endpoint is estimated to be approximately 33 people.



Pentane:  The worst-case release for pentane is a vapor cloud explosion resulting from a rupture of 65,000 pounds stored in the tank, which is located in a containment area.  According to EPA guidance for pentane vapor cloud explosions, the impact radius is 0.3 miles.  This places the toxic endpoint into residential areas, commercial industrial areas, and a recreational park.  The population within this endpoint is estimated to be approximately 566 people.



4.    Alternative Release Scenario



TDI:  The alternative case for a TDI spill is the rupture of a hole or leaking connection of a TDI unloading hose releasing for 30 minutes into a containment area of 4,536 ft2, located inside the facility.  The impact radius of this scenario is 0.04 miles.  This distance does not extend into the residential area and therefore impacts a population 0 people.



Pentane:  The alternative case for a pentane release is a vapor cloud fire from an evaporating pool created from a 3" pipe breaking while the tank is full.  This scenario involves a release of 1,802 lbs/min for

10 minutes.  The impact radius of this scenario 0.1 miles.  This places the toxic endpoint area in the residential area next to our facility.  The population within this endpoint is estimated to be 99 people.



5.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps



This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all applicable State of Texas codes and regulations required by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  Personnel training with air packs and practice drills for emergencies and spill response are an important part of our safety and preventive measures.



6.    Five Year Accident Histories



No accidents have occurred with the Pentane process within the last 5 years.  This would include the time frame of March 2011 through March 2016.



There was one TDI accident in January 2015.  A release of 2,200 gallons of TDI/Polyol mixture that was contained on site which resulted in 3 onsite employee injuries.  No offsite injuries or damage reported..  





7.    The Emergency Response Program



This program is referred to as the Emergency (Integrated Contingency) Plan for the Temple Division.  It is reviewed and revised on a yearly basis, unless immediate changes are needed as a result of equipment or personnel changes.  It includes a listing of the trained Spill Response Team and Fire Emergency Action Team.  The teams are trained to respond to an emergency spill or fire when the alarm is sounded, or incident is noticed.  Information with regards to the hazardous chemicals on site has been given to the local fire department, police department, and hospitals.



8.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Employees are regularly scheduled for Hazardous Materials Handling training as well as spill drills.  Training in the use of SCBA equipment is conducted regularly with the spill team.
